Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Templated Synthesis of Protein Conjugates
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Artem Melman of the Department of Chemistry & Biomolecular Science at Clarkson University will explore the development of new methods for the site specific derivatization of recombinant proteins. Current methods for covalent derivatization of proteins are not selective, producing complex mixtures of protein conjugates. The proposed approach will rely on formation of metal complexes with the hexahistidine sequence that is present in most recombinant proteins as a template for subsequent intramolecular alkylation of one of the histidine residues of the hexahistidine sequence. The project will involve study of ternary metal complexes of hexahistidine with other chelate ligands, design and synthesis of histidine alkylating agents, and chemoselectivity of their reactions with different nucleophiles. Based on these studies, new hexahistidine alkylating reagents will be prepared and tested for selective derivatization of model recombinant proteins.

This work is anticipated to lead to efficient methods for derivatization of proteins and production of functional protein conjugates. Development of these methods will have impact on several research fields using chemically modified proteins including biochemistry, synthetic biology, and medicinal chemistry. Possible applications of new protein conjugates include new targeted drug delivery, early diagnostics of diseases, and determination of structure and functions of proteins in biological systems. In addition, this project will provide advance training of undergraduate and graduate students, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research was directed toward development of precise chemical modification of molecules of proteins. These chemically modified proteins are important for study of the origin of diseases, their early diagnostics, and selective treatment. Most of currently existing methods for these modifications produce complex mixtures of products that are modified at different sites. The obtained mixtures are difficult to separate which substantially complicated these processes and compromise purity of modified proteins. Furthermore, these chemical modifications require laborious optimization of reaction conditions to obtain acceptable yield and purity of desired proteins.

Our approach attempted to utilize a common fragment, hexahistidine tag, which is present in a majority of artificially prepared proteins as the site for the precise chemical modification. This was achieved through formation of a labile ternary complex between the hexahistidine tag, a specially designed reagent, a metal cation, which serves as a template for the subsequent formation of a chemical bond between the reagent and the protein. As a result, selective modification can be achieved at the hexahistidine tag without undesired interference with other reactive sites at the protein thus producing the modification with a high degree of purity from an arbitrary protein containing the hexahistidine tag using the standard procedure.

Our experiments on model compounds and proteins confirmed feasibility of the approach. Using the new family of reagents we successfully attached a fluorescent label to hexahistidine tag of a model protein. We have demonstrated that this modification can be performed in two stage manner in which the first selective reaction introduced “sticky end” function. The “sticky end” is then used for subsequent modification of the protein with a variety of fluorescent labels, toxins, or any other functions using known bioorthogonal reactions. This method has attracted a considerable interest from researchers working in the field of analysis of proteins. We are currently preparing specialized reagent kits for selective derivatization of recombinant proteins with functional groups needed by these researchers.

The project involved training of two graduate and seven undergraduate students including students from families underrepresented in graduate education.  The obtained results have been published in five technical papers, and presented on seven conferences and five seminars. The new technology for proteins modification was patented (US 20140046040 pending) and its commercialization is in progress.
